awd_titl_txt: Scripps Center for Oceans and Human Health
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide NSF support for the establishment of the Scripps Center for Oceans and Human Health at the Scripps Institute of Oceanography of the University of California - San Diego.  The Scripps COHH research team will apply a multidisciplinary approach to elucidate the marine cycling of small, natural, brominated, aromatic compounds that share chemical characteristics with some anthropogenic contaminants. The study will be focused in the Southern California Bight where we have applied a new non-targeted analytical approach to demonstrate the presence of >300 halogenated organic compounds in dolphins - an apex marine predator - feeding either offshore or inshore. As many as 30% of these compounds contain bromine and have no known anthropogenic source. In some cases, similar compounds have been previously hypothesized to be of natural origin in other marine environments. Given that these compounds bioaccumulate in apex marine predators they must be available to enter human populations through seafood consumption. 

These brominated, likely natural organic compounds will be the focus od Center activity for two main reasons. First, although several studies have documented the presence of these purported natural compounds in top predators, most have been unable to delineate trophic transfer, and no study has definitively identified source organisms. the team has recently identified a biosynthetic cluster in a marine bacterium that is capable of producing most of the carbon skeletons and bromination patterns of interest. To establish spatial patterns and ubiquity of source organisms they will continue to characterize this biosynthetic pathway through culture studies and examine environmental distributions through metagenomics. Furthermore, by using our non-targeted analytical approach to comprehensively survey all trophic levels in benthic and pelagic habitats they will directly demonstrate how these compounds enter apex predators. This will further enable us to delineate potential pathways by which these compounds enter human populations.

Secondly, the presence of these compounds in apex predators indicates that they must enter the human population via seafood consumption, but this has not been documented. To test this the team will apply a non-targeted method to analyze breast milk from local mothers who have been surveyed to document their seafood consumption habits. Since these compounds resemble anthropogenic contaminants such as PBDEs, PCBs and PCDDs, they are expected to have similar toxic effects in both humans and wildlife. Brominated, natural compounds that are most abundant in dolphins have pyrrole backbones and their toxic impacts are poorly documented, and so, they will examine the potential toxicity of these compounds in the zebra fish model. Together, these efforts seek to identify source organisms and biosynthetic mechanisms of production, and also delineate modes of transfer to human populations. 

Broader Impacts. A more complete picture of the marine cycling of these compounds will enable us to assess how global change may impact sources -- something that up to now has been impossible. Furthermore, we will be in a position to assess the role that the burgeoning aquaculture industry and general seafood consumption plays in transferring these compounds to human populations. The Center organizational structure and ongoing collaborations with NOAA and local water resources management agencies will insure that the research approach and findings benefit from the input of individuals who dictate public health policy decisions, carry out environmental monitoring, and manage resources. The Center web portal (www.scohh.ucsd.edu) and personal outreach efforts will also keep the public informed and engaged in our research activities through interaction with K-12 classrooms and local communities. A special effort will be made to engage URM undergraduates in the Center's research through participation in the UCSD STARS program, the SIO NSF-sponsored SURF program and the UCSD-Howard University Pathways program. 

JOINT FUNDING BY NSF AND NIEHS:  The original proposal on which this project is based (P01 ES021921-01) was submitted to the National Institutes of Environmental Health Sciences (NIH/NIEHS) in response to Funding Opportunity Announcement RFA-ES-11-012 , "Centers for Oceans Human Health (P01)?" an opportunity jointly sponsored by NSF.   This project is cooperatively funded through separate awards from NSF and NIEHS.

por.por_cntn:
We discovered approximately 300, non-PCB and non-DDT, halogenated organic compounds (HOCs) in Tursiops truncatus (common bottlenose dolphin) in the Southern California Bight (SCB) and as a comparison site, the southwestern Atlantic Ocean, using a new analytical approach. Many of the 327 HOCs in blubber from two ecotypes in the SCB, consisted of anthropogenic contaminants (persistent organic pollutants or POPs), but ~40 natural HOCs were also definitively identified (including the brominated diphenyl ethers (MeO-BDEs specifically) and polybrominated pyrroles (MBPs and DMPBs)), and nearly 100 HOCs did not have a known library match.  Natural HOCs were, in some cases, detected at abundances similar to anthropogenic compounds. The profile of naturally occurring HOCs differed between ecotypes, suggesting more abundant offshore sources of these compounds. At both sites, detected natural HOCs appeared to cycle similarly to POPs. However, given their natural source, we propose that these compounds serve as important benchmarks against which to examine the changing landscape of anthropogenic HOCs. Furthermore, their ubiquity provides a useful model for examining how natural systems modify and metabolize HOCs.

We discovered that polybrominated HOCs such as hydroxylated brominated diphenyl ethers (OH-BDEs) and polybrominated pyrroles (MBPs and DMPBs), which have been reported to accumulate in marine biota, are produced by marine bacteria, both free living bacteria of the genera Pseudoalteromonas and Marinomonas and tropical sponge microbiome-associated cyanobacteria of the genus Hormoscilla.

We decoded polybrominated aromatic compound biosynthesis in marine bacterial genomes through the discovery and functional characterization of the brominated marine pyrrole/phenol (bmp) biosynthetic gene cluster. This gene cluster provides an important handle for examining the diversity and distribution of natural HOCs in marine and terrestrial environments.

Although the products of this biosynthetic pathway appear to accumulate in a variety of marine foodwebs our research found that bmp genes are restricted in their distribution within limited Pseudoalteromonas, Marinomonas, and Hormoscilla marine bacterial species.

We discovered and rigorously characterized novel enzymes that install and remove bromine atoms in polybrominated HOCs, thereby establishing the molecular basis for polybrominated biochemical construction in nature. Debrominase enzymes appear to behave like enzymes that perform similar chemistries in human systems, and so, provide an interesting model system in which to explore their mechanism of action.

We deduced an alternative abiotic mechanism for the construction of environmental polybrominated pyrrole chemicals via ozone-mediated catalysis. Similar reactions may be taking place in wastewater treatment facilities for example, and also in other environments including in atmospheric particles.

We established the previously undescribed biological mechanism of the marine bacterial compound tetrabromopyrrole as a potent and selective activator of the human ryanodine receptor and inhibitor of microsomal sarcoplasmic/endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase, thereby reporting for the first time the human health concern for this natural as well as disinfection byproduct chemical.

We found a positive a correlation between endocrine disruption and selected HOCs in Southern California marine mammals (Delphinus delphis).

We discovered that in general, the SCB cetacean species (long-beaked common dolphin, short-beaked common dolphin, and Risso?s dolphin) averaged 128 HOCs, whereas pinnipeds in the same environment (California sea lion and Pacific harbor seal) averaged 47 HOCs. We suspect this disparity can be attributed to differences in life history, foraging strategies, and/or enzyme-mediated metabolism. The use of a sentinel marine species together with our newly developed method for detecting these diverse HOCs will enable a proactive approach to environmental contaminant monitoring.

A collaboration with Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution has shown that some natural MBPs and DMBPs detected in the marine environment are able to bind to and activate the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR), through which many of the anthropogenic halogenated aromatic hydrocarbons act to cause toxicity. The relative potencies of some MBPs and DMBPs are similar to those of mono-ortho PCBs. Natural MBPs, in addition to activating the AHR, may have other effects on developing embryos as suggested by experiments with zebrafish embryos.

We found significant associations between seafood consumption before and during pregnancy and HOC body burden in San Diego breastfeeding mothers. Amount of fish consumption, frequency of fish consumption, types of fish, and cooking methods were significantly associated with increased concentrations of HOCs in the breast milk samples. Based on these results we advocate for similar studies to be conducted for a larger subset of the population to ensure that the observed correlation between seafood consumption and HOC body burden are robust. Furthermore, because the benefits of seafood consumption during pregnancy are significant, we need to provide relevant toxicity data for HOC concentrations found in this study. As such, the results of our study are not conclusive enough to influence dietary practices of pregnant and breastfeeding mothers. However, they do argue for further research in this area.
